title: The Online Discount Algorithms Need To Chill Out
sub_head: I just wanted a good deal on T-shirts, not daily offers to buy more and more of them
body:
Last month I began a desperate search for the black cotton T-shirts I have been wearing for years. I did this because my present stock of T-shirts was getting faded and raggedy—but also because I am trying to support the retail sector of this country in its hour of need.
For reasons that are not clear, my local department stores did not have the black T-shirts in stock, only the white ones. Eventually I hit on the obvious solution and decided to order the shirts online, directly from the manufacturer. But at some point in the payment process, I made the fatal decision to surrender my email address, so that the manufacturer could alert me to massive discounts and flash sales.
At first, even the manufacturer did not have the size or color I wanted, so I put the whole project aside. In a few hours, I received a message basically asking “Did you forget something?” Just in that short time, my size and color had come in, so I ordered a half-dozen. The price was not great, nor was the shipping, but the shirts did arrive in a few days, and I could finally toss the old ones into the trash and congratulate myself on a job well done.
That’s when the emails really started coming. At all hours of the night and day, they would whisper to me—or scream. 25% off. 40% off! Free shipping. 25% off and free shipping! Last chance for 75% off and free shipping!!
I like being alerted to fantastic discounts on quality merchandise. And free shipping. I really do. The problem is, there is only so much underwear that any one person can wear at any one time.
